activated-charcoal.name: Activated charcoal
activated-charcoal.description: Activated carbon powder from plant sources. Creates deep black to grey colours. Add at trace.

sourcing.productionMethod: Carbonization of plant materials (coconut shells, bamboo, wood) followed by activation.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Usually made from coconut shells (sustainable byproduct) or bamboo. Source material varies by manufacturer.

references.section: Cosmetic use concentrations 0.001-10%

annatto-extract.name: Annatto extract
annatto-extract.description: Extract from Bixa orellana seeds. Contains bixin (oil-soluble) and norbixin (water-soluble). Permitted in cosmetics under EU Regulation 1223/2009.

sourcing.productionMethod: Extracted from Bixa orellana seed coating using oil or alkali.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Supports smallholder farmers in tropical regions. Sustainable crop with low environmental impact.

references.section: Phytochemistry, biological activities and potential of annatto in natural colorant production

bentonite-clay.name: Bentonite clay
bentonite-clay.description: Montmorillonite-rich clay. Swells 12-15x when wet. Cation exchange capacity ~100 meq/100g. Higher absorption than kaolin.

sourcing.productionMethod: Open-pit or underground mining, then processed and purified.

environmental: Mining operations can disrupt local ecosystems
ethicalConcerns.notes: Mined mineral with established global supply chains. Wyoming is a major source of high-quality bentonite.

references.section: Bentonite, Kaolin and Selected Clay Minerals, Section 2.2

calendula-petals.name: Calendula petals (dried)
calendula-petals.description: Dried Calendula officinalis flowers. Only botanical that retains colour in high pH soap. Use for decoration or oil infusion.

sourcing.productionMethod: Cultivated Calendula officinalis flowers, harvested and dried.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Widely cultivated medicinal herb with established agricultural supply chains.

references.section: European Union herbal monograph on Calendula officinalis L., flos (Revision 1)

chamomile-flowers.name: Chamomile flowers (dried)
chamomile-flowers.description: Dried Matricaria chamomilla flowers. Use for decoration (crispy-dry only) or tea infusion for lye. Turn brown over time in soap.

sourcing.productionMethod: Cultivated Matricaria chamomilla flowers, harvested and dried.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Widely cultivated medicinal herb. Egyptian chamomile is highly valued.

references.section: Amended Safety Assessment of Chamomilla recutita-Derived Ingredients as Used in Cosmetics

chromium-oxide-green.name: Chromium oxide green
chromium-oxide-green.description: Chromium(III) oxide (Cr2O3). CI 77288. Permitted in cosmetics under EU Regulation 1223/2009. Not for lip products. Stable at high pH.

sourcing.productionMethod: Synthesized from chromite ore or recycled chromium sources.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Synthetic pigment derived from chromium mining. Cosmetic-grade chromium oxide is highly purified.

references.section: Chromium(III) oxide (CID 517277)

french-green-clay.name: French green clay (illite)
french-green-clay.description: Illite clay. Green colour from iron oxides and decomposed plant matter. Similar absorption properties to kaolin.

sourcing.productionMethod: Mined and processed illite clay deposits.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Named for the Montmorillon region of France. Also mined in other countries.

references.section: Bentonite, Kaolin and Selected Clay Minerals, Section 2.3

indigo-powder.name: Indigo powder
indigo-powder.description: Natural indigo from Indigofera tinctoria. Contains indigotin. Not approved for eyes, lips, or nails.

sourcing.productionMethod: Extracted from Indigofera tinctoria leaves through fermentation and oxidation.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Traditional dye plant. India is the historic centre of natural indigo production.

references.section: Opinion on hair dye Indigofera tinctoria (SCCS/1615/20)

iron-oxide-black.name: Iron oxide black
iron-oxide-black.description: Iron(II,III) oxide (Fe3O4). CI 77499. Permitted in cosmetics under EU Regulation 1223/2009. Stable in high pH. Use sparingly.

sourcing.productionMethod: Synthetic precipitation from iron salts (cosmetic grade) or mined natural deposits.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Cosmetic-grade iron oxides are typically synthetic for purity and heavy metal control.

references.section: Iron(II,III) oxide Fe3O4 (CID 16211978)

iron-oxide-red.name: Iron oxide red
iron-oxide-red.description: Iron(III) oxide (Fe2O3). CI 77491. Permitted in cosmetics under EU Regulation 1223/2009. Stable in high pH.

sourcing.productionMethod: Synthetic precipitation from iron salts (cosmetic grade) or mined natural deposits.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Cosmetic-grade iron oxides are typically synthetic for purity and heavy metal control.

references.section: Iron(III) oxide Fe2O3 (CID 518696)

iron-oxide-yellow.name: Iron oxide yellow
iron-oxide-yellow.description: Iron(III) oxide hydroxide (FeO(OH)). CI 77492. Permitted in cosmetics under EU Regulation 1223/2009. Stable in high pH.

sourcing.productionMethod: Synthetic precipitation from iron salts (cosmetic grade) or mined natural deposits.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Cosmetic-grade iron oxides are typically synthetic for purity and heavy metal control.

references.section: Iron oxide hydroxide FeOOH - Pigment Yellow 42 (CID 23320441)

kaolin-clay.name: Kaolin clay (white)
kaolin-clay.description: Hydrated aluminum silicate (Al2Si2O5(OH)4). Particle size 0.1-4 micrometers. Cation exchange capacity 2-10 meq/100g. Can absorb essential oils.

sourcing.productionMethod: Mined and refined from kaolinite deposits.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Georgia (USA) is a major source of high-quality kaolin. Well-regulated mining industry.

references.section: Bentonite, Kaolin and Selected Clay Minerals, Section 2.1

mica-iron-oxide.name: Mica (iron oxide coated)
mica-iron-oxide.description: Mica coated with iron oxides (â‰¤55% by weight). Creates bronze, copper, gold effects. Color-stable in high pH soap.

sourcing.productionMethod: Natural mica mined, then coated with iron oxides in industrial process.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: India produces ~60% of global mica. Synthetic mica is an alternative.

environmental: Illegal mining degrades forests in India
social: Child labour documented in Indian mica mines (Jharkhand/Bihar)
Unsafe working conditions in informal mining operations
Deaths and injuries from mine collapses
ethicalConcerns.notes: Indian mica mining has severe child labour and safety issues. Responsible Mica Initiative works to address concerns. Synthetic (fluorphlogopite) mica avoids mining concerns entirely. Verify sourcing from RMI members or synthetic sources.

references.section: Safety Assessment of Mica as Used in Cosmetics

mica-pearl-titanium.name: Mica pearl (titanium dioxide)
mica-pearl-titanium.description: Natural or synthetic mica coated with titanium dioxide (TiO2). Creates interference/pearl effects. Color-stable in CP soap.

sourcing.productionMethod: Natural mica mined, then coated with titanium dioxide in industrial process.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: India produces ~60% of global mica. Synthetic mica is an alternative.

environmental: Illegal mining degrades forests in India
social: Child labour documented in Indian mica mines (Jharkhand/Bihar)
Unsafe working conditions in informal mining operations
Deaths and injuries from mine collapses
ethicalConcerns.notes: Indian mica mining has severe child labour and safety issues. Responsible Mica Initiative works to address concerns. Synthetic (fluorphlogopite) mica avoids mining concerns entirely. Verify sourcing from RMI members or synthetic sources.

references.section: Mica-Based Pearlescent Pigments

rose-petals.name: Rose petals (dried)
rose-petals.description: Dried Rosa spp. petals. Turn brown in CP soap due to high pH. Add only to top of cured soap for decoration.

sourcing.productionMethod: Cultivated Rosa spp. flowers, harvested and dried.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Often a byproduct of rose oil/water distillation. Bulgaria's Rose Valley is a major source.

references.section: Safety Assessment of Rosa damascena-Derived Ingredients as Used in Cosmetics

spirulina-powder.name: Spirulina powder
spirulina-powder.description: Dried blue-green algae (Limnospira spp.) powder. pH-stable natural colourant. Rich in phycocyanin.

sourcing.productionMethod: Cultivated in controlled ponds or closed photobioreactors, then harvested and dried.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Sustainable microalgae cultivation. Low environmental impact compared to traditional agriculture.

references.section: Spirulina as Key Ingredient in Eco-Friendly Cosmetics

titanium-dioxide.name: Titanium dioxide
titanium-dioxide.description: Titanium(IV) oxide (TiO2). CI 77891. Permitted in cosmetics under EU Regulation 1223/2009. Creates opaque white. Stable in high pH.

sourcing.productionMethod: Extracted from ilmenite or rutile ore through chloride or sulfate process.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Major industrial mineral. China is the largest producer of titanium dioxide.

references.section: Opinion on Titanium Dioxide (TiO2) used in cosmetic products (SCCS/1516/13)

turmeric-powder.name: Turmeric powder
turmeric-powder.description: Ground rhizome of Curcuma longa. Contains curcumin (90%+ curcuminoids). Permitted as food colourant (E100) but not listed for cosmetics in EU Regulation 1223/2009.

sourcing.productionMethod: Ground Curcuma longa rhizome, dried and powdered.

ethicalConcerns.notes: India produces ~80% of global turmeric. Important smallholder crop.

references.section: Potential of Curcumin in Skin Disorders

ultramarine-blue.name: Ultramarine blue
ultramarine-blue.description: Synthetic sodium aluminum sulfosilicate. CI 77007. Permitted in cosmetics under EU Regulation 1223/2009. Stable at high pH.

sourcing.productionMethod: Synthetic pigment made by heating kaolin, sulfur, sodium carbonate, and carbon.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Fully synthetic pigment with no mining concerns. Historical ultramarine was made from lapis lazuli.

references.section: Ultramarine Blue - C.I. Pigment Blue 29 (CID 71587188)

ultramarine-pink.name: Ultramarine pink
ultramarine-pink.description: Sodium aluminum sulfosilicate violet/pink. CI 77007. Permitted in cosmetics under EU Regulation 1223/2009. Not for lip products.

sourcing.productionMethod: Synthetic pigment variation of ultramarine blue process.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Fully synthetic pigment with no mining concerns.

references.section: Sodium aluminosilicate Violet (CID 91667813)

zinc-oxide.name: Zinc oxide
zinc-oxide.description: Zinc oxide (ZnO). CI 77947. Permitted in cosmetics under EU Regulation 1223/2009. Creates opaque white.

sourcing.productionMethod: Produced from zinc ore (sphalerite) or recycled zinc via direct or indirect process.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Major industrial mineral with established global supply chains. China is the largest producer.

references.section: Safety Assessment of Zinc Salts as Used in Cosmetics
